questions.question_text:
A technician is setting up a SOHO wireless router and needs to adhere to the following requirements:
* The router should not assign network addresses to any device.
* All devices in the office must be able to access network resources and the Internet.
Which of the following should the technician perform to meet these requirements?

choices.A: Assign static IP addresses on all devices.
choices.D: Enable port forwarding for all devices.
choices.B: Set up MAC filtering for all devices.
choices.C: Place all devices in a DMZ.

discussion.content: Network address = IP address, so just assign static IPs and keep it the same
I agree with A but can also be B I think

comments.content: I did think the same to start with, set static IP's for every machine and then implement mac filtering to prevent anyone else connecting. But if you are assigning static IP's for ALL your machines i guess you could just disable the DHCP server then only machines with an assigned IP could connect right? (Aside from using MAC spoofing, which MAC filtering wouldn't prevent either)
It will limit who can join the network, so even if DHCP is available devices who are not on the list will not get an ip address from dhcp, so A and B technically accomplish the same thing
No, only A is viable. MAC filtering restricts access, it cannot be used for network routing.

questions.question_text: With which of the following types is a man-in-the-middle attack associated?

discussion.content:
Explanation
OBJ-2.5: A man-in-the-middle attack (MITM) is an attack where the attacker secretly relays and possibly alters the communications between two parties who believe they are directly communicating with each other. One example of a MITM attack is active eavesdropping, in which the attacker makes independent connections with the victims and relays messages between them to make them believe they are talking directly to each other over a private connection, when in fact the entire conversation is controlled by the attacker. The attacker must be able to intercept all relevant messages passing between the two victims and inject new ones. Spoofing is often used as a method of injecting the attacker into the conversation path between the two parties.

Man-in-the-Middle Attack
A Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) attack is another specific type of spoofing attack where the attacker sits between two communicating hosts and transparently monitors, captures, and relays all communication between them. Man-in-the-middle attacks are used to gain access to authentication and network infrastructure information for future attacks, or to gain direct access to packet contents.
